displayName.text: Mount Sinai Morningside Emergency Department Entrance

formattedAddress: 443 W 113th St, New York, NY 10025, USA
adrFormatAddress: 443 W 113th St, New York, NY 10025, USA

originalText.text: There is no reason for a hospital to dismiss a patients worry over privacy when it comes to a doctor discussing reason for visit. Nor to discuss your symptoms or whatever the situation. Any conversation between the doctor and the patient should always be PRIVATE. Walking through the halls or isles in the ER is not a place for discussion. Being told you're crowded when you're not, as an excuse to being vocal about a patients diagnosis or treatment is ill-informed and inexcusable. It's Dr/patient 101. I explicitly stated on numerous occasions that privacy is a concern, they continued to speak loudly and amongst everyone surrounding us. I saw multiple empty rooms that we could have spoken in and they insisted it be done publicly. This was an issue at first when I entered the ER. Never a care amongst the staff. The two stars are because the Dr and nurse was thankfully efficient,  minus the fact that they could not find me when the nurse took me in and sat me in a room. The DR made an announcement over the PA that I need to make myself seen. Professionalism, OUT THE DOOR! MOUNT SINAI, truly needs to step it up. APPALLING.

originalText.text: Went to visit a friend in the ER and they said visiting hours were closed down for 4 hours, that was unacceptable. Unfortunately this wouldn't happen if the people there were predominantly caucasian and I find it disgusting that this happened. People come from long distances to visit people then have to turn around & leave. Where's the consideration and the compassion for people's lives.

originalText.text: I ask could i leave my contact information for my sick mother at the ER. the very short male doctor with the red or blond hair ignore me I wish I remember his name. Everyone Else in the ER very helpful I wish I knew their name to give them the credit they deserve.

originalText.text: Mt. Sinai St. Luke's Hospital is great for non POC to get excellent care. On the other hand, people of color are often treated lesser than and inhumane. The staff is rude---albeit overwhelmed. The support staff is more concerned with the politics of the workplace than doing their jobs with care and consideration of their patients. Some are treated with godspeed, but those have one thing in common----their lack of pigment. On the other hand, I've witnessed instances in the past where Black and Brown people with legitimate pain are treated as if they are drug addicts when they are in excruciating pain. I am a home health aide and my patient was told that it isn't fair for her to be taking up a bed when there are sicker patients----mind you she is a diabetic, and this particular visit was due to a condition with fluid in the lungs and she cannot catch her breath when she lies down. She saw a doctor once in the 8 hours she was there. The standard blood tests and X-rays were done. Some antibiotics even, but You guessed it. She was discharged. She was discharged even though she feels worse than when she came in. Her medication was also sent to a pharmacy that cannot fill the prescription until next week. I am making this a digital trail in case her condition worsens for the sake of a "sicker" patient. Earlier, she begged for a nurse to help her to a bathroom, but they carried on with their non work conversations and ignored her pleas causing her to soil herself. (These nurses  were less than 8 feet away from her sitting on their behinds.) This place feels like a money grab from black and brown folk, so that those resources may be allotted to THOSE who are afforded the privilege of kindness, care, consideration and thorough medical care. It's not fair for space to be taken from them I guess.

originalText.text: Very slowly, everything was dirty, the restrooms dirty, the nurses take a long time to assist you. I saw a nurse speaking quite badly to an a very older lady who just wanted to go to the restroom. The registration nurse did not include my health insurance information in my registration and when I discovered it by chance four days later, I told the nurse that the hospital was running very poorly, then with a cynical smile she replied yes, that's how it is and wasn't her fault.
